page.title: 03Farming in The Shelsleys
page.content: Along the valley bottom in the richer alluvium, rotation of crops like wheat and barley takes place with roots such as sugar beet and potatoes. On the less extreme slopes there is orchard, including commercial cider apples grown for{Bulmers.}A little cherry growing continues from trees now fifty years old and there is some commercial blackcurrant growing. On the flatter ground beef cattle are fattened and higher up sheep and store cattle, mainly Hereford cross with some Charolais, are pastured and calves reared; there is also one dairy unit. Sheep are largely Suffolk cross, Welsh half-bred or Clun. Deep litter battery production takes place at{Church Farm}, rearing 2000 turkeys for the Christmas market and in addition 2000 chickens on contract four times a year.
